Award.AwardTitle: CICI: Secure Data Architecture: STREAMS: Secure Transport and REsearch Architecture for Monitoring Stroke Recovery

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rehabilitation of stroke patients is a long but critical process for their long-term wellness. Monitoring patients with wearable sensors and web cameras can support at-home rehabilitation by reducing the risk of events such as accidental falls and inappropriate dietary intake. Such sensor-generated live data streams about patient status and activities are processed at data centers for real-time analytics, helping healthcare professionals to respond to patients' needs quickly and effectively. Since the data streams may contain electronic Protected Health Information (ePHI), they must be protected so that transmission and usage conform to security and privacy regulations, such as Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) and applicable state laws. Therefore, it is important to investigate advanced networking and computing technologies to meet these security requirements, which are critical for bringing sensors and data analytics from research to clinical environments.

This research plans to address the security challenges in transferring and processing patient related sensor data by developing a Secure Transport and REsearch Architecture for Monitoring Stroke Recovery (STREAMS), a technical proof-of-concept implementation, to secure end-to-end sensor data streams using secure software defined networking and elastic compute and storage resources. STREAMS will be the first prototype of a secure network architecture to provide advanced data analytics-based healthcare to stroke patients in a realistic clinical environment. This project addresses issues in securing heterogeneous sensory ePHI patient data. It captures the workflows of patient data analysis and defines a role-based security enforcement framework to apply access policies. A Secure SDN controller will be designed to authenticate, identify, and direct encrypted data streams to ensure the data streaming over the network are HIPAA compliant, provide guidance in provisioning of compute resources at the cloud, and apply the most appropriate decryption algorithms based on the role of users, priority, types and source of the sensor data stream, as well as network conditions. A generalizable secure hardware and software architecture collects, encrypts, decrypts, stores, transports, analyzes, and maintains the integrity and availability of the data from these multimodal sensors to enable them to be fused using analytics algorithms to learn about patient activities that are highly relevant to stroke recovery. The highly interdisciplinary project team consists of healthcare professionals, medical researchers, computer scientists, IT staff, engineering staff, and industrial partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
• Be written for the general public.
  • Describe the project outcomes or findings that address the intellectual merit and broader of impacts of your work as defined in the NSF merit review criteria.
  • Briefly summarize the outcomes of your award (200 - 800 words) covering the entire life of the award.

 

CICI-STREAMS project aimed to design a secure hardware and software architecture and algorithms to collect, encrypt, decrypt, store, transport, analyze, and maintain the integrity and availability of the data from these multimodal sensors, enabling it to be fused using analytics algorithms to learn about patient activities that are highly relevant to stroke recovery such as physical therapy and fall detection/prevention. We designed algorithms and methods for secure software defined network architecture to identify and direct encrypted data streams, supporting compliance requirements. We list a few major outcomes from this project as follows.

We collaborated with biomedical domain experts very closely on several major clinical applications including fall detection, fall risk prediction for stroke recovery monitoring, and mobile-cloud based food recognition and monitoring of dietary intake. The team has investigated and developed a set of new fall detection algorithms, including new fall detection algorithms based on acceleration magnitude values and non-linear time series analysis techniques, as well as new filtering techniques to facilitate fall detection process.The team has also developed new algorithms and computing system based on novel deep convolutional neural network (CNN) techniques to improve the accuracy of dietary estimation. In addition, team has researched and developed new algorithms that assess the patients rehabilitation activities systematically and provide low-latency quantitative biofeedback based on established clinical assessment tool. 

We worked closely with a licensed physical therapy clinician on assessment of human pose for in-home rehabilitation. A new image datasets for lower body rehabilitation was created and a number of lightweight deep learning models for human pose estimation were studied to facilitate in-home lower body rehabilitation. This new labeled image dataset consists of ground truth joint point locations, collected from 31 different types of lower body rehabilitation activities performed by volunteers, under the supervision of a licensed clinician. we redesigned a lightweight but powerful deep learning model to estimate human pose and the model is able to run on a smart phone. To the activity evaluation end, we further developed a series of principle to evaluate the patients' in-home rehabilitation activities. For the concern of privacy, all the data collected from patients are encrypted, stored and processed on patients' own smart phones. Only the evaluation reports are uploaded to the server and shared with the patients' primary doctors. By leveraging our system, patients are able to do lower body rehabilitation activities in home without the assistance of physical therapists. In this way, the rehabilitation process can be implemented with reduced cost while preserving privacy. 

We also enhanced the security of edge computing where the encrypted network traffic goes through programmable software defined infrastructure platforms. Without decrypting the network flows, we strive to detect malicious flows to identify and prevent attacks from comprising edge devices used in tele-health applications. For example, we studied the machine learning techniques to detect malicious encrypted network traffic in edge computing where telehealth applications thrive. Traditional approaches based on studying network patterns fail to operate on encrypted data, especially without compromising the integrity of encryption. In addition, the requirement of rendering network-wide intelligent protection in a timely manner further exacerbates the problem. In our work, we proposed to leverage using off-the-shelf general purpose multicore platforms provisioned at network edge with the software accelerators to design an encrypted traffic analytics system with faster speed. Specifically, we explored a suite of data features and machine learning models with an open dataset. The results showed that by using Intel DAAL and OpenVINO libraries in model training and inference, we were able to reduce the training and inference time by up to 31x and 46x respectively while retaining the model accuracy. 

The project has provided many opportunities for training the students on the state of art technology and real-world healthcare challenges. By working with professionals in the healthcare field, the students gained rare opportunity to understand the challenges in healthcare applications and search for solutions that are technologically capable and practically feasible and compliant. The project enriched the participants? knowledge in computing, networking and machine learning, cultivated their verbal and written communication skills, and taught them the importance of critical thinking and innovation.
